snippet: Britain’s chancellor of the Exchequer was teased by his Czech counterpart as Europe’s finance ministers failed to reach an accord on the amount of capital reserves required for banks.
abstract: Europe's finance ministers fail to reach an accord on the amount of capital reserves required for banks; Britain stands mostly alone after refusing to give its blessing to the deal. Photos (M)t
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS -- A meeting of European Union finance ministers turned a little unruly late Wednesday when George Osborne, Britain's chancellor of the Exchequer, accused his counterparts of making him look like an ''idiot'' because he pushed for approval of stricter banking laws. When the meeting finally broke up, Britain stood mostly alone among 27 European Union member states after refusing to give its blessing to a deal on capital requirements for banks to fortify them against a future crisis.

headline.main: Britain Remains a Dissenter as Europeans Try to Set Capital Reserves for Banks
